description: From Middle English caban, cabane, from Old French cabane, from Medieval Latin capanna (“a cabin”); see further etymology there. Doublet of cabana.

entries.meaning: (US) A small dwelling characteristic of the frontier, especially when built from logs with simple tools and not constructed by professional builders, but by those who meant to live in it.
examples: Abraham Lincoln was born in a log cabin.

entries.meaning: (informal) A chalet or lodge, especially one that can hold large groups of people.
A private room on a ship.
examples: the captain's cabin:  Passengers shall remain in their cabins.

entries.meaning: The interior of a boat, enclosed to create a small room, particularly for sleeping.
The passenger area of an airplane.
(travel, aviation) The section of a passenger plane having the same class of service.
A small room; an enclosed place.
(India) A private office; particularly of a doctor, businessman, lawyer, or other professional.

verbs.description: cabin (third-person singular simple present cabins, present participle cabining, simple past and past participle cabined)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To place in a cabin or other small space.
(by extension) To limit the scope of.
examples: There was a time when this Court’s precedents may have portended the kind of First Amendment liability for purely private property owners that the majority spends so much time rejecting.  […]  But the Court soon stanched that trend. See Lloyd Corp. v. Tanner, 407 U. S. 551, 561–567 (1972) (cabining Marsh and refusing to extend Logan Valley); Hudgens v. NLRB, 424 U. S. 507, 518 (1976) (making clear that “the rationale of Logan Valley did not survive” Lloyd).

entries.meaning: (intransitive, obsolete) To live in, or as if in, a cabin; to lodge.
